sp.speaker: Eudicus
sp.p: Why, then, are you silent, Socrates, when Hippias has been delivering such a fine display? Why do you not join us in praising some part of his speech, or else, if he seems to you to have been wrong in any point, refute him—especially now that we who might best claim to have a share in philosophical discussion have been left to ourselves?

sp.speaker: Socrates
Eudicus
sp.p: It is plain enough that Hippias will not object answering if you ask him a question. Oh, Hippias, if Socrates asks you a question, will you answer? or what will you do?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Why, Eudicus, it would be strange conduct on my part, if I, who always go up to Olympia to the festival of the Greeks from my home at Elis, and entering the sacred precinct, offer to speak on anything that anyone chooses of those subjects which I prepared for exhibition, and to answer any questions that anyone asks—should now avoid being questioned by Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are in a state of blessedness, Hippias, if at every Olympiad you come to the sanctuary with fair hopes concerning your soul and its wisdom; and I should be surprised if any of the physical athletes when he goes to that same place to take part in the contests, has such fearless confidence in his body as you have in your intellect.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Naturally, Socrates, I am in this state: for since I began to contend at the Olympic games, I never yet met anyone better than myself in anything.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is splendid, Hippias! Your reputation will be a monument of wisdom for the city of Elis and your parents. But now what do you say about Achilles and Odysseus? Which do you say is the better and in what respect? For when there were many of us in the room, and you were making your exhibition, I could not keep up with what you were saying: for I hesitated to ask questions, because there was a great crowd in the room, also for fear of hindering your exhibition by doing so; but now, since we are fewer and Eudicus here urges me to question you, speak and tell us clearly what you said about these two men; how did you distinguish them?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Why I am glad, Socrates, to explain to you still more clearly what I say about these and others also. For I say that Homer made Achilles the bravest man of those who went to Troy, and Nestor the wisest, and Odysseus the wiliest.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Oh dear, Hippias! Would you do me the favour not to laugh at me if I find it hard to understand what you say, and keep asking questions over and over? Please try to answer me gently and courteously.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Of course; for it would be a disgrace, Socrates, if I, who teach others good manners and charge them money for it, should not myself, when questioned by you, be considerate and reply gently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is excellent. For when you said that the poet made Achilles the bravest of men, and Nestor the wisest, I thought I understood what you meant; but when you said that he made Odysseus the wiliest, to tell you the truth, I do not in the least know what you mean by that. Now tell me, and perhaps it may result in my understanding better. Has not Homer made Achilles wily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p:
Not at all, Socrates; he made him most simple; for in “The Prayers,” when he depicts them talking with one another, he makes Achilles say to Odysseus: The division into twenty-four books was made in Alexandrian times. Before that division was made (and even after) references were made to parts of the Iliad and Odyssey by descriptive titles, “The Prayers,” “The Catalogue of Ships,” and the like.
Zeus-born son of Laertes, wily Odysseus, I must speak out the word without refraining, as I shall act and think will be accomplished [and pray do not mutter in discord sitting here beside me]. For hateful to me as the gates of Hades is he who hides one thing in his heart and says another. But I shall speak that which shall be accomplished.Hom. Il. 308 ff.In these lines he makes plain the character of each of the men, that Achilles is true and simple, and Odysseus wily and false for he represents Achilles as saying these lines to Odysseus.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now at last, Hippias, I think I understand what you mean; you mean that the wily man is false, apparently.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Certainly, Socrates; for Homer represents Odysseus as that sort of a man in many passages of both Iliad and Odyssey.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Homer, then, as it seems, thought that a true man was one man and a false man another, but not the same.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Of course he did, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you think so yourself, Hippias?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Most assuredly; for it would be strange if I did not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us drop Homer, since it is impossible to ask him what he meant when he made those verses; but since you come forward to take up his cause, and agree in this which you say is his meaning, do you answer for Homer and yourself in common.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Very well; ask briefly whatever you like.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you say that the false are, like the sick, without power to do anything, or that they have power to do something?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: I say that they have great power to do many things, and especially to deceive people.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: They are, then, powerful, according to you, and wily, are they not?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But are they wily and deceivers by reason of simplicity and folly, or by reason of shrewdness and a sort of intelligence?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: By shrewdness, most assuredly, and intelligence.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: They are intelligent, then, as it seems.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, by Zeus, too much so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And being intelligent, do they know what they are doing, or do they not know?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, they know very well; that is why they do harm.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And knowing these things which they know, are they ignorant, or wise?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Wise, surely, in just this, deception.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Stop. Let us recall what you say. You say that the false are powerful and intelligent, and knowing and wise in those things in which they are false?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that the true and the false are different and complete opposites of one another?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, the false are among the powerful and the wise, according to your statement.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And when you say that the false are powerful and wise for falsehood, do you mean that they have power to utter falsehoods if they like, or that they are powerless in respect to the falsehoods which they utter?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: That they have power.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In short, then, the false are those who are wise and powerful in uttering falsehoods.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: A man, then, who has not the power to utter falsehoods and is ignorant would not be false.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, but every man has power who does what he wishes at the time when he wishes; I am not speaking of one who is prevented by disease or that sort of thing, but as I might say of you that you have power to write my name when you wish or do you not say that a man has power who is in such a condition?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Tell me, then, Hippias, are you not skillful in arithmetical calculations?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Most assuredly, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if some one were to ask you what the product of three times seven hundred is, you could, if you wished, tell him the truth about that more quickly and better than anyone else?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because you are the most powerful and wisest of men in these matters?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are you, then, merely wisest and most powerful, or are you also best in those matters in which you are most powerful and wisest, namely calculations?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Best also, to be sure, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you would have the greatest power to tell the truth about these things, would you not?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But what of falsehoods about these same things? And please answer this with the same splendid frankness as my previous questions, Hippias. If some one were to ask you how much three times seven hundred is, would you have the most power to tell falsehoods and always uniformly to say false things about these matters, if you wished to tell falsehoods and never to reply truly; or would he who is ignorant of calculations have more power to tell falsehoods than you, if you wished to do so? Or would the ignorant man often, when he wished to tell falsehoods, involuntarily tell the truth, if it so happened, because he did not know, whereas you, the wise man, if you wished to tell falsehoods, would tell them always and uniformly?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, it is as you say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is the false man, then, false about other things, but not about number, and would he not tell falsehoods when dealing with number?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: He is false about number also, by Zeus.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we, then, assume this also, that there is such a person as a man who is false about calculation and number?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now who would that man be? Must he not, as you just now agreed, have power to tell falsehoods, if he is to be false? For it was said by you, if you recollect, that he who has not the power to tell falsehoods would never be false.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, I recollect, that was said.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And just now you were found to have most power to tell falsehoods about calculations, were you not?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, that also was said.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Have you, then, also most power to tell the truth about calculations?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the same man has most power to speak both falsehood and truth about calculations; and this man is the one who is good in respect to them, namely the calculator.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Who, then, becomes false in respect to calculation, Hippias, other than the good man? For the same man is also powerful and he is also true.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: So it appears.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You see, then, that the same man is both false and true in respect to these matters, and the true is in no wise better than the false? For he is indeed the same man, and the two are not utter opposites, as you thought just now.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Apparently not, at least in this field.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we, then, investigate elsewhere?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: If you like.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, are you expert in geometry also?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, has not the same man most power to speak falsehood and truth about geometry, namely the geometrician?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In respect to that, then, is any other good than he?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: No, no other.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The good and wise geometrician, then, has the most power in both respects, has he not? And if anyone is false in respect to diagrams, it would be this man, the good geometrician? For he has the power, and the bad one was powerless, to speak falsehood; so that he who has no power to speak falsehood would not become false, as has been agreed.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, then, investigate also the third man, the astronomer, whose art you think you know even better than those of the previous ones; do you not, Hippias?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are not the same things true in astronomy also?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Probably, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then in astronomy also, if anyone is false, the good astronomer will be false, he who has power to speak falsehood. For he who has not power will not for he is ignorant.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: So it appears.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The same man, then, in astronomy will be true and false.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
Hippias
sp.p: But I cannot, Socrates, at least, not now offhand.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you never will be able to tell me, I fancy; but if what I say is true, Hippias, you remember what results from our argument.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: I do not at all understand what you mean, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, for perhaps you are not using your art of memory; for you evidently think it is not necessary; but I will remind you. Do you remember that you said that Achilles was true and Odysseus was false and wily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you now, then, perceive that the same man has been found to be false and true, so that if Odysseus was false, he becomes also true, and if Achilles was true, he becomes also false, and the two men are not different from one another, nor opposites, but alike?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Socrates, you are always making intricate arguments of this sort, and, picking out the most difficult part of the argument, you stick to it in detail, and you do not discuss the whole subject with which the argument deals; for now, if you like, I will prove to you by satisfactory argument based on many pieces of evidence, that Homer made Achilles better than Odysseus and free from falsehood, and Odysseus crafty and a teller of many falsehoods and inferior to Achilles. And, if you like, do you oppose argument to argument, maintaining that the other is better; and these gentlemen here will determine which of us speaks better.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
Hippias, I do not doubt that you are wiser than I; but it is always my custom to pay attention when anyone is speaking, especially when the speaker seems to me to be wise; and because I desire to learn what he means, I question him thoroughly and examine and compare the things he says, in order that I may learn. But if the speaker seems to me to be worthless, I neither ask questions nor care what he says. And by this you will recognize whom I regard as wise; for you will find me persistently asking such a man questions about what he says, in order that I may profit by learning something. And so now I noticed when you were speaking, that in the lines which you repeated just now to show that Achilles speaks to Odysseus as to a deceiver, it seems to me very strange, if what you say is true, that Odysseus the wily is nowhere found to have spoken falsely, but Achilles is found to be a wily sort of person, according to your argument; at any rate, he speaks falsely. For he begins by speaking these lines which you just quoted:
For hateful to me as the gates of Hades is he who hides one thing in his heart and says another,Hom. Il. 9.312 ff. and a little later says that he would not be persuaded by Odysseus and Agamemnon and would not stay at Troy at all, but,—
Tomorrow, after sacrificing to Zeus and all the gods, (he says), I will load my ships well and drag them into the sea; then you shall see, if you like and if it interests you, early in the morning my ships sailing the fishy Hellespont and my men eagerly rowing in them; and if the glorious Earthshaker should grant me a fair voyage, on the third day I should come to fertile Phthia.Hom. Il. 9.357 ff.And even before that, when he was reviling Agamemnon, he said:
And now I shall go to Phthia, since it is far better to go home with my beaked ships, and I do not intend to stay here without honor, and heap up wealth and riches for you.Hom. Il. 1.169 ff.After he has said these things, at one time in the presence of the whole army and at another before his own comrades, he is nowhere found to have either prepared or attempted to drag down his ships to sail home, but he shows quite superb disregard of truthspeaking. Now I, Hippias, asked my question in the first place because I was perplexed as to which of the two men is represented as better by the poet, and because I thought both were very good, and it was hard to decide which was better, both in regard to falsehood and truth and to virtue in general; for both are similar in this matter.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: That is because you do not look at it aright, Socrates. For the falsehoods that Achilles utters, he utters evidently not by design, but against his will, since he is forced by the misfortune of the army to remain and give assistance; but Odysseus utters his falsehoods voluntarily and by design.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are deceiving me, beloved Hippias, and are yourself imitating Odysseus.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Not at all, Socrates. What do you mean and to what do you refer?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That you say Achilles did not speak falsely by design, he who was not only a deceiver, but was also such a cheat and plotter, as Homer has represented him, that he is seen to be so much more clever than Odysseus in deceiving him unnoticed without difficulty, that he dared to contradict himself in his presence, and Odysseus did not notice it; at any rate Odysseus does not appear to have said anything to him which indicates that he noticed his falsehood.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: What is this that you say, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Don't you know that after he said to Odysseus that he was going to sail away at daybreak, in speaking to Ajax he does not repeat that he is going to sail away, but says something different?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Where, pray?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
Where he says:
For I shall not be mindful of bloody war until warlike Priam's son, the glorious Hector, shall reach the tents and ships of the Myrmidons through slaughter of Argives and shall burn the ships with fire. But at my tent and my black ship I think Hector, though eager for battle, will come to a halt.Hom. Il. 9.360 ff. Now, Hippias, do you think the son of Thetis and pupil of the most wise Cheiron was so forgetful, that, although a little earlier he had reviled deceivers in the most extreme terms, he himself immediately said to Odysseus that he was going to sail away and to Ajax that he was going to stay, and was not acting by design and in the belief that Odysseus was behind the times and that he himself would get the better of him in just this matter of contrivance and falsehood?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: No, I do not agree, Socrates; but in this case also Achilles was induced by the goodness of his heart to say to Ajax something different from what he had said to Odysseus; whereas Odysseus, when he speaks the truth always speaks with design, and when he speaks falsehood likewise.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then Odysseus, as it seems, is better than Achilles.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Not in the least, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How is that? Were not those who utter falsehoods voluntarily found to be better than those who do so involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: And how, Socrates, could those who voluntarily do wrong and voluntarily and designedly do harm be better than those who do so involuntarily? And there seems to be good reason to forgive a man who unwittingly does wrong or speaks falsehood or does any other evil. And the laws surely are much more severe towards those who do evil and tell falsehoods voluntarily, than towards those who do so involuntarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you see, Hippias, that I speak the truth when I say that I am persistent in questioning wise men? And this is probably the only good thing about me, as I am otherwise quite worthless; for I am all wrong about facts, and do not know the truth about them. And it is to me sufficient proof of the truth of this, that when I come into contact with one of you who are famous for wisdom, and to whose wisdom all the Greeks bear witness, I am found to know nothing; for there is hardly a single thing about which you and I have the same opinion; and yet what greater proof of ignorance is there than when one disagrees with a wise man? But I have this one remarkable good quality, which is my salvation; for I am not afraid to learn, but I inquire and ask questions and am very grateful to him who answers, and I never failed in gratitude to anyone; for when I have learned anything I have never denied it, pretending that the information was a discovery of my own; but I praise the wisdom of him who instructed me and proclaim what I learned from him. And so now I do not agree with what you say, but disagree very strongly; and I know very well that this is my own fault, because I am the sort of man I am—not to give myself any greater title. For my opinion, Hippias, is the exact opposite of what you say; I think that those who injure people and do wrong and speak falsehood and cheat and err voluntarily, not involuntarily, are better than those who do so involuntarily. Sometimes, however, the opposite of this seems to me to be the case, and I am all astray about these matters, evidently because I am ignorant; but now at the present moment a sort of paroxysm of my disease has come upon me, and those who err in respect to anything voluntarily appear to me better than those who err involuntarily. And I lay the blame for my present condition upon our previous argument, which causes those who do any of these things involuntarily to appear to me at this moment worse than those who do them voluntarily. So please do me a favour and do not refuse to cure my soul; for you will be doing me much more good if you cure my soul of ignorance, than if you were to cure my body of disease. Now if you choose to deliver a long speech, I tell you beforehand that you would not cure me—for I could not follow you—but if you are willing to answer me, as you did just now, you will do me a great deal of good, and I think you yourself will not be injured, either. And I might fairly call upon you also, son of Apemantus, for help; for you stirred me up to converse with Hippias; so now, if Hippias is unwilling to answer me, ask him in my behalf to do so.

sp.speaker: Eudicus
sp.p: Well, Socrates, I imagine Hippias will need no asking from us; for that is not what he announced; he announced that he would not avoid the questioning of any man. How is that, Hippias? Is not that what you said?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, I did; but Socrates, Eudicus, always makes confusion in arguments, and seems to want to make trouble.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Most excellent Hippias, I do not do these voluntarily at all—for then I should be wise and clever, according to you—but involuntarily, so forgive me; for you say,See 372. too, that he who does evil involuntarily ought to be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Eudicus
sp.p: And do not refuse, Hippias; but for our sake, and also because of your previous announcements, answer any questions Socrates asks you.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Well, I will answer since you request it. Ask whatever questions you like.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I certainly have a great desire, Hippias, to investigate what we are just at present talking about, namely which are better, those who err voluntarily or those who err involuntarily. Now I think the best way to go at the investigation is this. Just answer. Do you call some one a good runner?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And a bad one?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now, he who runs well is a good runner, and he who runs badly a bad one; is it not so?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then does not he who runs slowly run badly, and he who runs fast run well?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In a race, then, and in running, rapidity is a good thing, and slowness an evil.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Why, of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Which, then, is the better runner, he who runs slowly voluntarily or he who does so involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: He who does it voluntarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, is not running doing something?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, it is doing.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if doing, is it not also performing some act?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then he who runs badly performs a bad and disgraceful act in a race?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, a bad act of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But he runs badly who runs slowly?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the good runner performs this bad and disgraceful act voluntarily, and the bad runner involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In running, then, he who does bad acts involuntarily is worse than he who does them voluntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, in running.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And how is it in wrestling? Which is the better wrestler, he who is thrown voluntarily, or involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: He who is thrown voluntarily, as it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But is it worse and more disgraceful in a wrestling match to be thrown or to throw one's opponent?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: To be thrown.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In wrestling also, then, he who performs bad and disgraceful acts voluntarily is a better wrestler than he who performs them involuntarily.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And how is it in every other bodily exercise? Is not he who is the better man in respect to his body able to perform both kinds of acts, the strong and the weak, the disgraceful and the fine, so that whenever he performs bad acts of a bodily kind, he who is the better man in respect to his body does them voluntarily, but he who is worse does them involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: That seems to be the case in matters of strength also.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And how about grace, Hippias? Does not the better body take ugly and bad postures voluntarily, and the worse body involuntarily? Or what is your opinion?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: That is my opinion.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then ungracefulness when voluntary is associated with excellence of the body, but when involuntary with faultiness.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what do you say about the voice? Which do you say is the better? That which sings out of tune voluntarily, or involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: That which does it voluntarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that which does it involuntarily is the worse?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Would you choose to possess good or bad things?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Good ones.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Would you, then, choose to possess feet that limp voluntarily, or involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Voluntarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But is not a limp faultiness and ungracefulness of the feet?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, is not dimness of sight faultiness of the eyes?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Which eyes, then, would you choose to possess and live with? Those with which one would see dimly and incorrectly voluntarily, or involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Those with which one would do so voluntarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Those parts, then, of yourself which voluntarily act badly you consider better than those which do so involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes; that is, in matters of that sort.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, one statement embraces all alike, such as ears and nose and mouth and all the senses —that those which act badly involuntarily are undesirable because they are bad, and those which do so voluntarily are desirable because they are good.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, which instruments are better to have to do with, those with which a man does bad work voluntarily, or involuntarily? For instance, is a rudder better with which a man will involuntarily steer badly, or one with which he will do so voluntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: One with which he will do so voluntarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is not the same true of a bow and a lyre and flutes and all the rest?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Quite true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, would you choose to possess a horse of such spirit that you would ride him badly voluntarily, or involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Voluntarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then that spirit is better.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then with the horse of better spirit one would do voluntarily the bad acts of that spirit, but with the one of worse spirit involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is not that true of a dog, and all other animals?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, then, in the case of an archer is it better to possess the mind which voluntarily misses the mark, or that which does so involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: That which does so voluntarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then that is the better mind for the purpose of archery?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is, then, the mind also which errs involuntarily worse than that which errs voluntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, in the case of archery.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And how is it in the art of medicine? Is not the mind which does harm to the patients' bodies voluntarily the more scientific?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In this art, then, this mind is better than the other.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: It is better.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, the more musical, whether with lyre or with flute, and in everything else that concerns all the other arts and sciences—is not that mind better which voluntarily does bad and disgraceful things and commits errors, whereas that which does so involuntarily is worse?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And surely we should prefer to possess slaves of such minds that they voluntarily commit errors and do mischief, rather than such as do so involuntarily; we should think them better fitted for their duties.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, should we not wish to possess our own mind in the best possible condition?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Will it, then, be better if it does evil and errs voluntarily, or involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: But it would be a terrible thing, Socrates, if those who do wrong voluntarily are to be better than those who do so involuntarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But surely they appear, at least, to be so, from what has been said.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Not to me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I thought, Hippias, they appeared to be so to you also. But now once more answer me: Is not justice either a sort of power or knowledge, or both? Or must not justice inevitably be one or other of these

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then injustice is a power of the soul, the more powerful soul is the more just, is it not? For we found, my friend, that such a soul was better.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes, we did.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if it be knowledge? Is not the wiser soul more just, and the more ignorant more unjust?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if it be both? Is not the soul which has both, power and knowledge, more just, and the more ignorant more unjust? Is that not inevitably the case?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: It appears to be.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: This more powerful and wiser soul, then, was found to be better and to have more power to do both good and disgraceful acts in every kind of action was it not?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whenever, then, it does disgraceful acts, it does them voluntarily, by reason of power and art; and these, either one or both of them, are attributes of justice.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And doing injustice is doing evil acts, and not doing injustice is doing good acts.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Will not, then, the more powerful and better soul, when it does injustice, do it voluntarily, and the bad soul involuntarily?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is not, then, a good man he who has a good soul, and a bad man he who has a bad one?

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is, then, in the nature of the good man to do injustice voluntarily, and of the bad man to do it involuntarily, that is, if the good man has a good soul.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: But surely he has.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then he who voluntarily errs and does disgraceful and unjust acts, Hippias, if there be such a man, would be no other than the good man.

sp.speaker: Hippias
sp.p: I cannot agree with you, Socrates, in that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor I with myself, Hippias; but that appears at the moment to be the inevitable result of our argument; however, as I was saying all along, in respect to these matters I go astray, up and down, and never hold the same opinion; and that I, or any other ordinary man, go astray is not surprising; but if you wise men likewise go astray, that is a terrible thing for us also, if even when we have come to you we are not to cease from our straying.
